content: I've added the tag "Connected components".

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Original graph problem +1 I approve after my comment feedback has been fixed

This is a nice and original graph problem I've enjoyed resolving, arguably medium ~ hard but hard is fine to me.
I'm ready to approve but there is a problem with the parsing of the first input line, some languages' default code don't work because there are spaces after the number (Clojure, D, OCaml, Scala and Swift stubs fail to parse correctly)
Please trim it :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: After discussion, approved
Same exact issue, as your other contribution. Even your solution is sometimes times out, so either reduce the large tests, or provide a better solution yourself :)

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Testing quest

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this contribution because I like losing files.

I retract my previous comment about it risking being too easy, even though I'm great at post-rationalizing an intuitive explanation around it, I did have to get Google out to pinpoint the planar graph characteristic formula.
So this ends up as one of those puzzles with a very concise solution that's hard anyway. (you'll get some hate for that, be prepared ;) Which is fine with me.
yikes

This is great! I liked the story, and the question over all was quite good. This does need some prerequisite knowledge though. Mainly graph theory imo. Over all great question, would love to see it coming as a clash of code question.

Great, compelling story.

In my opinion, it deserves the Hard rating. Finding continents is quite easy. But counting tiles is rather harder, unless you studied graph theory.

Great, compelling story.

In my opinion, it deserves the Hard rating. Finding continents is quite easy. But counting tiles is rather harder, unless you studied graph theory.

Ok, second great write-up in a row, I'm hereby subscribing to your newsletter.

Feedback:

* you mention "non self-intersecting" for the tiles, so this begs the question: "oh, so they can intersect each other between tiles?" Ironically, neither would really make the puzzle any more complex, just the pictures.

* I had a pause at the "seed known => we can regenerate" that I (think I) wouldn't have if it came after the "we need to recover N and T". Pause = trying to figure out how to reverse the RNG to generate edges, when really it's both the wrong approach and off-topic. But I'll concede the text flows pretty well as is, which wouldn't necessarily be the case the other way round.

* I suspect this comes from mixing up the word "input"'s context between the map generator and the puzzle. So I'd suggest 1) not using the word input at all in the statement section, and 2) repeating "N and T" when that's what's talked about.

* BTW, they're called N and T in the statement, but C and T in I/O.

* a common vertex joins continents, but those in the pictures all share an entire edge.

This is really my HQ-puzzle feedback game, aiming to minimize false starts. None of it is required to have the contribution accepted.

(Oh, and I don't think this warrants hard either, but I don't think my opinion on puzzle difficulties is worth that much nowadays)

Add constraint [[n1]] < [[n2]]
(assuming that's how it's working, that could be useful info)
Well written, compelling back story - no idea how to solve it but I now have a desire to learn! Of course in my case it may be better to cancel the contest ... :D

Interesting puzzle, I like it.
Change word "context" to "contest". :)
What happens if two tiles share only 1 vertex? Is it considered 1 continent or 2 or will such a case not appear?
Example:
0 --- 1 --- 2
  \    / \    /
    \/     \/
    3      4

Thanks, I fixed  the typo. 
"2 tiles belong to the same continent if they  share at least 1 vertex" => so there is only  1 continent  in  your  example.
Should I replace "at least one" with "one or more"? I think both are synonyms but the second one may be clearer...

This inequality is not always true, for example there is a 30 22 edge in example 2 (and most edges have indeed n1 > n2 toward the end of the inputs).

The order of n1 and n2, as well the order of the edges is not relevant (I randomized the node labels during generation, then sorted edges at the end). Maybe I should not sort the edges to emphasize this...

Thanks a lot for your detailed feedback:
 - I removed the "non self-intersecting" which only added confusion
 - I also removed ambiguous usage of "input" as you suggested
 - I fixed the "N" vs "C" discrepancy
You just copied another person's comment
You don't say

"Testing quest" ? What does it mean?
Could  you  please  clarify ?

I generated new maps for the two big cases with half size.
Note that my solution would be much much faster with 03 optimization enabled, which I do not enable on purpose to allow using slower languages.

I fixed the trailing space.
Since you were the 3rd person to suggest it,  I also decreased the difficulty.
Thanks for your feedback.
BTW I suspect CG to have some technical issues, because I got a timeout for the smallest case with size 13, which run in O(13)...
Validating the quest on the map was bugged now it works (at least when we reject contribution)
Ok I see :-)
Done: I fully randomized all inputs to make it clear.
